title: S.Korea's after-retirement business start-ups grow in 2019
content:
SEOUL, Dec. 29 (Xinhua) -- South Korea's after-retirement business start-ups grew last year as the rising number of the elderly people continued to work after retirement, statistical office data showed Tuesday.
The total number of businesses nationwide stood at 4,175,286 as of the end of 2019, up 72,114, or 1.8 percent, from a year earlier, according to Statistics Korea.
The number of businesses, owned by those in their 60s or higher, advanced 34,756, or 3.7 percent, from a year ago to 961,827 at the end of 2019.
The elderly-owned business growth took up nearly half of the total business increase as the higher number of the elderly people started business after retirement, the statistical office said.
The number of business owners in their 50s added 1.9 percent over the year to 1,444,823 last year, and the reading for those in their 20s or lower expanded 4.5 percent to 108,456.
The figures for those in their 30s and 40s inched up to 526,770 and 1,133,410 respectively.
The number of businesses in the eatery and lodging sector climbed 2.5 percent, with the readings for those in transport and real estate segments growing 2.2 percent and 5.3 percent each.
A total of 3,321,837 businesses hired four or lower employees as of end-2019, while 834,088 businesses had workers between five and 99. Enditem
